headline: Joe Manchin targeted by millions of dollars in ad buys from all sides
sentences:
MANCHIN SAYS HE ‘CANNOT VOTE’ FOR BUILD BACK BETTER: ‘I’VE DONE EVERYTHING HUMANLY POSSIBLE'
Manchin and fellow moderate Sen. Kyrsten Sinema, D-Ariz., have effectively sunk several progressive bills like the Democrats’ voting rights bill and the social spending Build Back Better bill by refusing to go around the filibuster’s 60-vote threshold.

Manchin, a moderate Democrat, has enjoyed an outsized influence in the Senate since Biden took office, with the Democrats holding a razor-thin 50-50 majority (including two independents who caucus with Democrats and Vice President Kamala Harris as a tie-breaker).

The Democrats haven't passed President Biden's Build Back Better plan – but West Virginia has been seeing a boost in at least one sector of the state's economy, thanks to efforts by all sides to influence U.S. Sen. Joe Manchin.

Media outlets in the Mountain State have benefited from ad buys totaling $10 million between September and the end of last year, from both Republicans and Democrats, according to the Charleston Gazette-Mail.
In late November, six House Democrats up for re-election and seven Democrats seeking U.S. Senate seats ran negative attack ads on Manchin in his home state, according to the Gazette-Mail.
Consequently, Manchin is often the brunt of Democratic frustration as Biden’s agenda stalls in Congress while he is lauded by Republicans.
Last month, a Republican-aligned group launched a $1 million ad campaign to pressure Manchin to support the filibuster, NBC News reported.
Sanders last fall also appealed directly to Manchin's constituents, penning an op-ed in the Gazette-Mail, slamming his fellow senator.
"Yet, the political problem we face is that in a 50-50 Senate we need every Democratic senator to vote 'yes,' We now have only 48.
Just over a dozen Democrats have also run more than 700 ads targeting Manchin on Facebook and Instagram, according to Newsweek.
Progressive Sen. Bernie Sanders, I-Vt., suggested last month he’d be open to supporting primary challengers to Manchin.
"There’s a very good chance" of Manchin getting Democratic challengers, Sanders said in January, according to The Hill.
"Joe Manchin just said he can't support the Build Back Better Act after MONTHS of stringing along negotiations."
"Poll after poll shows overwhelming support for this legislation," Sanders wrote of the Build Back Better bill.
Manchin answered back that he wasn't going to take orders from a "self-declared Independent socialist."
Democratic U.S. Rep. Tim Ryan of Ohio said in an ad on social media, according to Newsweek.
Two Democratic senators remain in opposition, including Sen. Joe Manchin."
More ad money is being spent on other platforms, the report added.
Former President Trump won 68% of West Virginia’s vote in 2020.
Tell him to protect the Senate filibuster," the ad said.
Manchin and Sinema are both up for re-election in 2024.
Manchin responded, "I’ve been primaried my entire life.
The Associated Press contributed to this report.
I’ve never run an election I wasn’t primaried.
This is West Virginia, it’s rough and tumble.
"It’s up to the people of those states."
That would not be anything new for me.
Tell him to keep his promise.
He is running for the Senate.
"Call Senator Manchin.
"Folks, I'm P---ED!"
We’re used to that.
So bring it on."
